Why can you walk without slipping? Why does a rubber chappal grip better than a leather sole on a wet floor? The answer is friction â€” the force that opposes relative motion between two surfaces in contact.

ðŸ’¡ The Simple Core

Friction acts opposite to the direction of motion or attempted motion. It depends on the normal force (how hard the surfaces press together) and the coefficient of friction (Î¼). Formula: f = Î¼N. Types: Static friction prevents an object from starting to move; Kinetic friction acts on moving objects; Rolling friction acts on rolling objects (smallest of the three).

ðŸŽ¯ The Show

Pushing a heavy almirah: you need to overcome static friction first (it's large!), then kinetic friction keeps it moving. A bicycle wheel has rolling friction â€” that's why cycling is easier than pushing. Oiling a door hinge reduces friction between metal surfaces. On railway tracks, a thin layer of oil reduces wear â€” but not at the braking surfaces, where friction is essential for stopping safely!
